questions.question: What are the three families of ester-based SPEs investigated in the study?
questions.answer: Polycarbonate electrolytes (PCE), polyoxalate electrolytes (POE), and polymalonate electrolytes (PME).

questions.question: Which diol-based polymer structures showed higher Li+-conductivity, and why?
questions.answer: Pentanediol (C5-diol) based polymer structures showed higher Li+-conductivity due to enhanced asymmetry and flexibility.

questions.question: How does the introduction of trifluoroacetyl-units affect the SPEs' compatibility with Li-metal?
questions.answer: The introduction of trifluoroacetyl-units protects the highly reactive OH units, enabling the generation of a LiF-based SEI passivating layer and improving the SPEs' compatibility with Li-metal.

questions.question: What was the observed effect of dimethyl-group introduction into malonate on the cycling stability of Li/PME/NCM622?
questions.answer: The introduction of the dimethyl-group into malonate suppressed enol isomerization, recovering the cycling stability of Li/PME/NCM622.

questions.question: Why did the ASS Li/NCM622 cells using C5-PME-F show severe capacity fading?
questions.answer: The severe capacity fading was attributed to the enol isomerization of malonate units in PME, which led to the dissolution of transition metals into SPE during cycling.

questions.question: What was the role of the trifluoroacetyl-units in enhancing the SPEs' performance?
questions.answer: Trifluoroacetyl-units protected the SPEs from chain decomposition, shifted HOMO electrons to the middle of main chains to protect polymers from oxidation, and facilitated the generation of a LiF-based SEI layer for improved interfacial stability with Li-metal.

questions.question: How did the SPEs' molecular design influence their Li+-conductivity and compatibility with high-voltage cathodes?
questions.answer: The SPEs' molecular design, including the type of ester-based family, diol segment length, and introduction of trifluoroacetyl-units, influenced their Li+-conductivity by affecting molecular asymmetry, flexibility, and interfacial stability with Li-metal and high-voltage cathodes.

questions.question: Is the introduction of TF-diol units in polymer main chains effective in generating a stable interface with Li-metal?
questions.answer: False. TF-diol units in polymer main chains were not effective in generating a stable interface with Li-metal.

questions.question: Did the ASS Li/NCM622 cells using C5-PME-F-Li exhibit stable cycling performance?
questions.answer: False. The ASS Li/NCM622 cells using C5-PME-F-Li exhibited severe capacity fading due to enol isomerization of malonate units.

questions.question: Does the dimethyl-modified PME (DM-C5-PME-F) show improved compatibility with Li-metal compared to C5-PME-F?
questions.answer: True. DM-C5-PME-F showed improved compatibility with Li-metal by suppressing enol isomerization, leading to stable cycling performance in ASS Li/NCM622 cells.

questions.question: Can the ASS Li/NCM622 cells using C5-POE-F-Li operate at room temperature?
questions.answer: True. The ASS Li/NCM622 cells using C5-POE-F-Li were tested at reduced temperatures, including room temperature, showing stable cycling performance.

questions.question: Are all SPEs synthesized in the study equally effective in stabilizing the interface with high-voltage cathodes?
questions.answer: False. Not all SPEs were equally effective; C5-PME-F showed severe capacity fading with high-voltage cathodes, which was improved by using dimethyl-modified PME.

questions.question: Does the introduction of trifluoroacetyl-units into SPEs lower their thermal stability?
questions.answer: False. The introduction of trifluoroacetyl-units into SPEs was observed to enhance their thermal stability.

questions.question: Is the LiF-based SEI layer generated by the in situ reaction of SPEs with Li-metal critical for their performance?
questions.answer: True. The generation of a LiF-based SEI layer by the in situ reaction of SPEs with Li-metal is critical for improving interfacial stability and overall performance.

questions.question: Did the study find that all SPEs synthesized have similar Li+-conductivity?
questions.answer: False. The study found variations in Li+-conductivity among the SPEs, with PME showing the highest conductivity due to stronger coordination with Li+.

questions.question: What impact does the length of the diol segment have on the SPEs' properties?
questions.answer: The length of the diol segment, specifically the use of C5-diol over C4-diol, impacts the SPEs' properties by enhancing molecular asymmetry and flexibility, which in turn improves Li+-conductivity.

questions.question: How does the coordination capability with Li+ influence the molecular design of SPEs?
questions.answer: The coordination capability with Li+ is critical for the molecular design of SPEs as it influences Li+-conductivity, molecular asymmetry, and the existing modes of elemental F, affecting the SPEs' overall performance.

questions.question: What role does molecular asymmetry play in the design of SPEs?
questions.answer: Molecular asymmetry plays a significant role in the design of SPEs by facilitating the improvement of Li+-conductivity through the suppression of molecular aggregation and enhancement of polymer chain flexibility.

questions.question: Is the cycling stability of Li/PME/NCM622 inherently poor without modifications?
questions.answer: True. The cycling stability of Li/PME/NCM622 is inherently poor due to enol isomerization of malonate units, which can be improved with modifications such as the introduction of a dimethyl-group.

questions.question: Does the study suggest that all SPEs synthesized are suitable for use in all-solid-state batteries at high temperatures?
questions.answer: False. The study suggests that while some SPEs show promise, not all synthesized SPEs are equally suitable for use in all-solid-state batteries, especially at high temperatures without specific modifications.
